- To **hack** something is to cut or slice at it without care to precision. For example, you could [wield](/wiki/Wield "Wield") a [weapon](/wiki/Weapon "Weapon") and hack a [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster"). See **[melee](/wiki/Melee "Melee")**.
- The game of ***Hack*** was a clone of *[Rogue](/wiki/Rogue_\(game\) "Rogue (game)")* named for the gameplay of hacking monsters. This game is the direct ancestor of *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. [Jay Fenlason](/wiki/Jay_Fenlason "Jay Fenlason") started this game; see **[Jay Fenlason's Hack](/wiki/Jay_Fenlason%27s_Hack "Jay Fenlason's Hack")**. [Andries Brouwer](/wiki/Andries_Brouwer "Andries Brouwer") made several changes and distributed the game over [Usenet](/wiki/Usenet "Usenet"); see **[Hack 1.0](/wiki/Hack_1.0 "Hack 1.0")** through **[Hack 1.0.3](/wiki/Hack_1.0.3 "Hack 1.0.3")**. It was [Mike Stephenson](/wiki/Mike_Stephenson "Mike Stephenson") who added the "Net" prefix to distinguish the later game.
- The Jargon File approximates a **hack** as *"an appropriate application of ingenuity"*. This term is popular among computer programmers who hack on [source code](/wiki/Source_code "Source code") to make it do something. The end result of hacking on NetHack is often a **[patch](/wiki/Patch "Patch")**.

References: [hack (dict.org)](http://www.dict.org/bin/Dict?Form=Dict2\&Database=*\&Query=hack), [The Meaning of 'Hack' (Jargon File 4.4.7)](http://www.catb.org/jargon/html/meaning-of-hack.html).

***

*This is a [disambiguation](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Disambiguation "NetHackWiki:Disambiguation") page: a list of articles associated with the same title.*  
*If an [internal link](https://nethackwiki.com/wiki/Special:WhatLinksHere/Hack) led you here, you may wish to change the link to point directly to the intended page.*

  • To hack something is to cut or slice at it without care to precision. For example, you could wield a weapon and hack a monster. See melee.
  • The game of Hack was a clone of Rogue named for the gameplay of hacking monsters. This game is the direct ancestor of NetHack. Jay Fenlason started this game; see Jay Fenlason's Hack. Andries Brouwer made several changes and distributed the game over Usenet; see Hack 1.0 through Hack 1.0.3. It was Mike Stephenson who added the "Net" prefix to distinguish the later game.
  • The Jargon File approximates a hack as "an appropriate application of ingenuity". This term is popular among computer programmers who hack on source code to make it do something. The end result of hacking on NetHack is often a patch.

References: hack (dict.org), The Meaning of 'Hack' (Jargon File 4.4.7).
